linkTarget.anchoringText: Well WI-01 was drilled and initially completed as dump-flood from aquifer Unit A into Unit D in 1977. In 1980 well was converted to single injector in Unit D after isolating aquifer with a 7″ scab liner. In 2004, well was shut-in due to high annulus pressure, and sidetracked to Unit F, re-completed as dual injector in Unit D & Unit F. The 7″ liner was cement squeezed and tied back to surface. A location map (Fig.1) and a wellbore schematic (Fig.2), showing current status, are shown below.

Well WI-01 was drilled and initially completed as dump-flood from aquifer Unit A into Unit D in 1977. In 1980 well was converted to single injector in Unit D after isolating aquifer with a 7″ scab liner. In 2004, well was shut-in due to high annulus pressure, and sidetracked to Unit F, re-completed as dual injector in Unit D & Unit F. The 7″ liner was cement squeezed and tied back to surface. A location map (Fig.1) and a wellbore schematic (Fig.2), showing current status, are shown below.

Spectral Noise Log is used to identify active flow units, differentiate matrix and fracture flow, detect behind-casing channeling or leaks in well completion. Multichannel spectral noise logging (SNL) tool has high-sensitive sensor to track noises behind multiple barriers. The interpretation of the Spectral Noise Logging data is based on amplitude-frequency analysis. The SNL is characterized by carrying out multiple lab tests and field studies which show noise frequency as a function of fluid movement in different medium and rock types. The noise frequency patterns are shown in the Fig.3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Typical noise frequency patterns for different flow scenarios.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical noise frequency patterns for different flow scenarios.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well was logged after 72 hour's shut-in to acquire stabilized temperature. The tools were run in Long String under three conditions: Shut-in (both strings), injecting in the Short String only, and Transient (time-elapsed under shut in) conditions. A summary is shown in the Table below and in Fig.4. HPT was logged while RIH at 16.0 ft./min and the SNL was logged during POOH with stations every 3 feet.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Logging schematic: The logging started with Shut-in run and followed by injection into SS string and transient condition HPT-SNL survey.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Logging schematic: The logging started with Shut-in run and followed by injection into SS string and transient condition HPT-SNL survey.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5-8 shows acquired data along with interpretation results. With LS shut-in and injection through SS, no pressure change in long string was observed, indicating no communication between the strings. A regional heating anomaly was observed across unit A (Fig 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: HPT survey under Flowing and Static conditions. The regional anomalies were identified above and below packer zones

formatted-caption.caption-text: HPT survey under Flowing and Static conditions. The regional anomalies were identified above and below packer zones

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5-8 shows acquired data along with interpretation results. With LS shut-in and injection through SS, no pressure change in long string was observed, indicating no communication between the strings. A regional heating anomaly was observed across unit A (Fig 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: HPT & SNL survey while SS injection showing also Transient Temp Profile. The survey revealed a thief injection zone into a non-perforated Unit B.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5-8 shows acquired data along with interpretation results. With LS shut-in and injection through SS, no pressure change in long string was observed, indicating no communication between the strings. A regional heating anomaly was observed across unit A (Fig 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: HPT & SNL survey under static condition. The Crossflow between UNIT-C and UNIT-B was identified while the well was shut-in: The temperature change in gradient and captured by SNL reservoirs activity indicated upward channelling through cement.

formatted-caption.caption-text: HPT & SNL survey under static condition. The Crossflow between UNIT-C and UNIT-B was identified while the well was shut-in: The temperature change in gradient and captured by SNL reservoirs activity indicated upward channelling through cement.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5-8 shows acquired data along with interpretation results. With LS shut-in and injection through SS, no pressure change in long string was observed, indicating no communication between the strings. A regional heating anomaly was observed across unit A (Fig 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: The oxygen activation log confirmed the existing behind casing water flow between Unit B and Unit D: The count rate increases from unit B.
